div.p: Either send or deliver the enclosed to Lady D as you like best - It is a note of thanks for Sir A D's discourses

Admirable! indeed my dear Francis, is this preface to the library for the diffusion of useful knowledge - Fanny & I have just finished reading it and I am impatient to pour out my admiration to you - I wish to God you had written it! - Is it possible that Brougham could write it - I cannot believe it - with his head his time so filled by politics No it is impossible - I can conceive that a man of his amazing versatility of powers & compass of mind might when furnished by scientific friends with materials have put the facts together in a brilliant and striking manner -

But it is the perfect sim- plicity & usefulness - of this
essay that I admire - the perfect adaptation of the means to the end - the compression - the proportion in which the vast variety of knowledge is kept - (Oh on a small scale I know how difficult that is to effect -) This must have been the result of great labor & great judgment - The knowledge must have been quite familiar to the mind to have come out at once so exact and so easy - & so well proportioned - again & again. I must say so well proportioned That is what strikes me as the greatest difficulty -
If Brougham wrote it he is the most wonderful man of the age - I except not Canning - I would rather have written this were I a man than have spoken Cannings finest speech

This calls new worlds into existence in a nobler
manner - & the author is not guilty of the egotism of "I called the new world into existence" -
Oh my dear Francis Now this essay would have delighted him who was most susceptible of any human being I ever knew of generous enthusiasm & pleasure in the abilities of others -
I see many things in that essay which prove the author had read Botany & Entomology
My dear Francis if you wrote it write instantly to me & tell me so for you could not possibly give me more exquisite pleasure

16 May 1827 1827 Mr E. The fairy lamp has arrived - It is beautiful - Pray send me another for my aunt Ruxton - It will be the most valuable because most useful present I can make her - Do not forget to send it, by Mr. Strickland - in his waist- coat pocket - I know he would carry it for me if he had no room anywhere else -

My dearest uncle - I perceive Maria has exhaled her expressions of admiration to you upon The Preliminary Treatise - which is so beautifully done that it must be of use There is no person (not absolutely inept) who has not some one taste touched upon here to be roused or stimulated with a desire for improve -ment - whose curiosity will not be excited - I do not remember ever to have read anything with so much pleasure - Arising from what Metaphysicians call the fitness of things - each science & each branch of that science is made to introduce the following so easily - so necessarily - There is besides a pleasure of the highest sort in the feeling of excellence in any one thing - Who is the supremely happy man who has succeeded in executing such a diffi -cult difficult task -? - If you know pray tell us directly - we are quite angry with Hunter now that we know his how much pleasure he detained from us so long -

I hope you allow yourself time to read the debates - they are very interesting as dis plays displays of individual character - & trials of skill - How doubly interesting to those who can hear them - There must be so much in the changes of countenance & the by play - where all is so personal that must be lost in cold black & white. As to the power of language the ins have it hollow
